title: Agents need 'better tools' to target LGBT market
text:
Save 
There need to be better tools available to travel agents in order to help educate them about the LGBT market, delegates were told. 
Speaking as part of a panel debate, Holiday Extra’s national partnerships manager Lindsay Garvey-Jones said more support should be given. 
“I don’t honestly feel that they [travel agents] have the tools or the skills to sensitively deal with the LGBT market and I just feel that we as an advisory board and our partners here today could produce a tool kit,” she said. 
Garvey-Jones said that the industry could also look towards Abta to educate staff. 
She added: “I would really like today to be a starting point for travel agents and the travel trade as a whole… because I think that what’s missing is the skill set there on sensitive questioning to send the right people to the right places.” 
Meanwhile, Stephen D’Alfonso, Abta’s head of public affairs defended big businesses over their efforts to target the sector. 
“ I think that [sponsoring an event like Pride] is a very good way of engaging with large segments of your consumer base that for the most part are individuals and rarely come together as a group and when they do, showing that support, even if it is in the most commercial of ways might be helpful.” 
Oliver Broad, director of RB Collection, said he believed companies such as Preferred Hotels were getting the message right when it came to the LGBT market.
